title: Anthony Lozano
text:
Anthony Rubén Lozano Colón (born 25 April 1993), also known as Choco Lozano, is a Honduran professional <a href="Association%20football">footballer</a> who plays as a <a href="forward%20%28association%20football%29">forward</a> for <a href="La%20Liga">La Liga</a> club <a href="C%C3%A1diz%20CF">Cádiz</a> and the <a href="Honduras%20%20national%20football%20team">Honduras national team</a>.
Club career.
Born in <a href="Yoro">Yoro</a>, Lozano made his debut in the <a href="Liga%20Nacional%20de%20F%C3%BAtbol%20Profesional%20de%20Honduras">Liga Nacional de Fútbol Profesional de Honduras</a> at the age of only 15, appearing for <a href="C.D.%20Olimpia">C.D. Olimpia</a> against <a href="Club%20Deportivo%20y%20Social%20Vida">Club Deportivo y Social Vida</a> on 11 January 2009. On 21 February 2010 he scored his first goals, netting a <a href="hat-trick">hat-trick</a> in the <a href="2009%E2%80%9310%20Honduran%20Liga%20Nacional%23Torneo%20Clausura">Clausura tournament</a> 6–0 win over <a href="C.D.%20Victoria">C.D. Victoria</a>.
In August 2010, Lozano spent time training with <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20F.C.">Tottenham Hotspur</a>'s <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20F.C.%20Reserves%20and%20Academy">reserve team</a>, impressing manager <a href="Harry%20Redknapp">Harry Redknapp</a>. He was expected to stay with the <a href="North%20London">North London</a> side, but the deal never went through because he was underage and, therefore, could not sign a contract with a professional club.
On 11 August 2011, Lozano moved to Spain and signed with <a href="Valencia%20CF">Valencia CF</a> on a one-year loan, but was immediately loaned to <a href="CD%20Alcoyano">CD Alcoyano</a> in <a href="Valencian%20Community">the same community</a>, in <a href="Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">Segunda División</a>. He made his official debut against <a href="UD%20Las%20Palmas">UD Las Palmas</a> on 3 September, as a second-half <a href="Substitute%20%28association%20football%29">substitute</a> (1–0 away loss).
Lozano spent the <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20B">2012–13 season</a> with <a href="Valencia%20CF%20Mestalla">Valencia's reserves</a>, in <a href="Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20B">Segunda División B</a>. After being released, he returned to his first club Olimpia.
Lozano was Olimpia's top scorer in the <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%20Honduran%20Liga%20Nacional">2014–15 campaign</a>, contributing 26 goals in 38 matches. On 6 August 2015, he returned to Spain and its second division after agreeing to a one-year loan deal with <a href="CD%20Tenerife">CD Tenerife</a>, which was extended on 9 July of the following year; he was awarded the <a href="Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20Player%20of%20the%20Month">Player of the Month award</a> for May, after helping his team reach <a href="2017%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20play-offs">the play-offs</a>.
On 7 July 2017, an agreement between <a href="FC%20Barcelona">FC Barcelona</a> and Olimpia for Lozano was confirmed by the latter club's vice president Osman Madrid, which saw the player become the first Honduran to represent the <a href="Catalonia">Catalans</a>. He was assigned to <a href="FC%20Barcelona%20B">their reserves</a> in division two, and in the first game of <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">the season</a>, he scored once and provided an <a href="Assist%20%28association%20football%29">assist</a> against <a href="Real%20Valladolid">Real Valladolid</a> (2–1, away).
On 30 January 2018, Lozano joined <a href="La%20Liga">La Liga</a> side <a href="Girona%20FC">Girona FC</a> for a fee of €1.7 million. He made his debut in the competition 12 days later, featuring 21 minutes in the 1–0 away loss to <a href="Sevilla%20FC">Sevilla FC</a>, and scored his first goal on 3 March – also from the bench – to help the visitors defeat <a href="Villarreal%20CF">Villarreal CF</a> 2–0.
Lozano was given a direct <a href="Penalty%20card%23Red%20card">red card</a> late into the 2–1 home win over <a href="Rayo%20Vallecano">Rayo Vallecano</a> on 27 October 2018, after tackling <a href="Santi%20Comesa%C3%B1a">Santi Comesaña</a> from behind. He scored the equaliser against <a href="Atl%C3%A9tico%20Madrid">Atlético Madrid</a> the following 9 January, cancelling out <a href="Antoine%20Griezmann">Antoine Griezmann</a>'s earlier goal in a 1–1 draw in the first leg of the <a href="Copa%20del%20Rey">Copa del Rey</a> <a href="2018%E2%80%9319%20Copa%20del%20Rey%23Round%20of%2016">round of 16</a> tie at the "<a href="Estadi%20Montilivi">Estadi Montilivi</a>"; it was his second competitive goal for the club, after failing to the find the net for almost a year. He once again scored in the cup when Girona faced <a href="Real%20Madrid%20CF">Real Madrid</a> in <a href="2018%E2%80%9319%20Copa%20del%20Rey%23Quarter-finals">the quarter-finals</a>, in the process becoming the fourth player from his country to achieve the feat against that opposition.
On 1 September 2019, Lozano was loaned to <a href="C%C3%A1diz%20CF">Cádiz CF</a> of the Spanish second tier for one year. He scored his first goal for the team late in the same month, in a 2–1 away win against <a href="UD%20Almer%C3%ADa">UD Almería</a>. He added a further nine until the end of <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">the campaign</a> – second-best in the squad behind <a href="%C3%81lex%20Fern%C3%A1ndez">Álex Fernández</a>'s 13 – as his team returned to the top flight after 14 years.
Cádiz exercised their option to buy on 22 July 2020, and Lozano signed a permanent three-year contract. On 17 October, he scored the only goal in a victory over Real Madrid at the <a href="Alfredo%20Di%20St%C3%A9fano%20Stadium">Alfredo Di Stéfano Stadium</a>, the first ever away against that adversary.
Lozano scored his first hat-trick in the Spanish first division on 26 October 2021, in a 3–3 draw at Villarreal.
International career.
Lozano scored 11 goals for the <a href="Honduras%20national%20under-17%20football%20team">Honduras under-17s</a>, including four in the <a href="2009%20CONCACAF%20U-17%20Championship">2009 CONCACAF Championship</a> which qualified the national team to <a href="2009%20FIFA%20U-17%20World%20Cup">that year</a>'s <a href="FIFA%20U-17%20World%20Cup">FIFA U-17 World Cup</a>, where he netted in the 3–1 loss against <a href="Germany%20national%20youth%20football%20team">Germany</a>. He made his <a href="Honduras%20national%20football%20team">senior debut</a> in August 2011, coming on as a <a href="Substitute%20%28association%20football%29">substitute</a> for <a href="Carlo%20Costly">Carlo Costly</a> (who scored both goals in the 2–0 win) in a <a href="Exhibition%20game">friendly</a> win over <a href="Venezuela%20national%20football%20team">Venezuela</a>.
Lozano also represented the country at the <a href="2012%20Summer%20Olympics">2012</a> and <a href="2016%20Summer%20Olympics">2016 Summer Olympics</a>. He scored twice in <a href="Football%20at%20the%202016%20Summer%20Olympics">the latter tournament</a>, helping <a href="Honduras%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">the nation</a> to the semi-finals in Brazil.
Personal life.
Lozano's half-brother, <a href="Luis%20Ramos%20%28Honduran%20footballer%29">Luis Ramos</a>, is also a footballer. A <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a>, he played several years in <a href="Slovakia">Slovakia</a> and <a href="Hungary">Hungary</a>. His style was compared to compatriot Costly. 
Lozano married Alessa Gámez, with the couple later welcoming a daughter.
